Entries.default:
"My brother calls the Wahaki the last true Huana. He is severe on the Kahanga, but I do not call him wrong." 

Onekaza thumbs her chin and nods.
"The tribe hates all foreigners. Passing ships are attacked on sight, and explorers never make it back to the beach."
"I have hesitated to let the trading companies see my teeth, but those days are behind us."
"I'll make contact with the Wahaki and hope for the best."
"I have questions before I agree to this."
"If I encounter any Wahaki on my travels, I'll consider your proposal."

"Sail for the isle of Ori o Koīki and return when you have an answer from the tribe, whether fair or foul.

"The island lies northwest of Neketaka."
"I assume you do not have a Wahaki gesture of fealty to lay at my feet?"
"Do the Wahaki pay the crown obeisance... in whatever eccentric form suits them?" Onekaza rests her chin on her fist and studies you.
"You can look forward to Wahaki support when the need arises."
"The Wahaki will not be joining us."
"Ask. I would not have you journeying to Ori o Koīki uninformed." She opens her palm to you and nods.
"I'd like to know more about the Wahaki."
"I've heard enough."
"Ekera, then you will seek out the Wahaki and bring their strength to the Kahanga?"
"As you will." She nods.
"I had some questions."
"What do you seek to gain from this alliance?"
"The Huana are always stronger together than we were apart. I want the Wahaki to remember this."
"I'll report in later."
"You have united the Huana with our missing limb." For once she allows herself a deep and genuine smile of gratitude.

"The Huana are strong, but our foes are stronger, richer, more relentless still.

"I say that the gods have delivered us an advantage we sorely need."
"They say you fought a detachment of warriors on Motare o Kōzi? Then you have seen their fury firsthand."
"I'd be surprised if you haven't traded blood with them once or twice in the past."
"You dealt with them peacefully on Motare o Kōzi. I am hoping you can make lightning strike a second time."
"It is said the Wahaki did unspeakable things to survive the downfall of our ancestors - cannibalizing the injured and making blood sacrifices to the gods."
"As the dust settled, the other tribes learned to keep their distance from the tribe."
"Those who do not think like my brother say the Wahaki never recovered from the loss of Ukaizo."
"The Wahaki warned us about entering Motare o Kōzi. I believe they are good at heart."
"If you would judge them on the basis of one chance meeting, that is your risk to take."
"On second thought, I'll return later."
"Ekera, only do not venture near Ori o Koīki without a plan in mind. The Wahaki do not welcome meandering voyagers."
"Ori o Koīki... what does that mean?"
"Ori o Koīki... the Cursed Land of Corpses?"
She raises her brow at Tekēhu.
"The Cursed Land of Corpses." Her lips slowly spread into a smile.
"Ekera, that would be the... Cursed Land of Corpses." He coughs gently into his fist.
"The corpses refer to the pungent koīki trees. The curse..." She shrugs.
"There are Engwithan ruins on the isle. I say our ancestors were either superstitious or had no taste for koīki."

"Are we still pitting cannons against canoes, highness?"

Maia glances up from furiously scribbling notes, her brow raised.
"Cannons exhaust themselves after every battle cry. My warriors do not."
"Today we are tribes, united under the gods. Tomorrow we can be an empire, and the Deadfire our protected haven."

"There is a phrase which will protect my royal herald. 'Over crumbling mountains, across blighted seas.' If you remember this, it could save your life." 

Onekaza dismisses you with a nod.

"I need allies, Watcher. For what do you bring me foul omens?" 

With reluctance she signals an attendant to pay you.

Her thoughts are turbulent, each one seven steps ahead of the last. 

She is more impressed that you made it back from Ori o Koīki alive.

"We need to be stronger than this, I say!" 

Onekaza brings her fist down on her armrest. Her tigers raise their heads.

"I cannot allow this setback to halt our advance on lost Ukaizo." 

She raises her knuckles to her mouth and sighs.
"Their loss, your majesty."
"The Wahaki should have come to us first."
"We are better off without the likes of them."
[Say nothing.]
"Ekera, unless they felt unwelcome in a court full of strangers."
"I am thinking we will regret the loss in these friendless times."
She raises her eyebrow and watches you go without comment.

"Prayer and the wisdom of Kohopa will help steer my next course. 

"I will send for you in time." Onekaza dismisses you with a wave.

"I have searched the skies over the Brass Citadel for smoke, but I see nothing but wisps of cloud." 

Onekaza pauses, raising her brow.

"Don't leave me waiting. Ukaizo has is too important to delay."

She sweeps her hand toward the stairs down.
"Go on."
"Hopefully they recognize me as a friend."
"Finally, a challenge."
"They will at least let you talk while they nock their arrows, I say."
"Ekera. And they do not like easy prey."
"I like them already."

"Filling the seas with Wahaki war canoes will strike terror in the heart of even Rauatai's iron fleet."

Onekaza smirks at the idea.
"Ekera - beyond what their warriors and sailors bring to the fight for Ukaizo?"
"I doubt I'll be a welcome sight... but I'll try."

"Ngati frowns on the Kahanga. This was a trial, a test of our fealty to the old ways.

"We failed her, I say."

"I will not fail her twice. A queen's work is not outdone by misfortune, and I am ready for her next trial!"

Many of Onekaza's attendants smile and bob their heads in support.

"When the cannons of our enemies go quiet, we will know peace again. This I know."

She gestures toward the stairs and nods, dismissing you.
"I had other questions."
"Farewell."
"I had other questions."
"Farewell."
"'Over crumbling mountains, across blighted seas.' I'll remember that."
"Write it down if you must, but recall it when the time comes. The Wahaki are not a trusting people." Onekaza nods and dismisses you with a wave.
"Before you rely too heavily on Wahaki support, you should know they consider me an enemy."
